Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving Performance and Retention of Engineering Graduate Students through Motivation and Identity Formation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This work is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation. This ECR project intends to understand how doctoral engineering student experiences influence identity formation and motivation and therefore affect retention, persistence and productivity. While this has been widely studied at the undergraduate level, graduate-level studies are less available. Engineering is the least studied fields in graduate education, and if studied, is often combined with other STEM fields, despite unique disciplinary cultures. Engineering culture traditionally values industry-driven careers over academically-driven careers. The focus on career preparation and industry-relevant experiences can also lead to limited development of research-oriented skills and future goals by engineering students. Students coming in with limited definitions of research, particularly research in an engineering context, can experience a mismatch between their identities, their future goals and expectations for them as researchers. The proposed work could benefit engineering graduate students who may be at risk of abandoning their educational pursuits in engineering. Increasing retention of talented individuals in graduate engineering programs increases the number of individuals who can train the new graduates needed to solve the next generation of engineering problems. Unique approaches to problems solved by engineers are essential as growing global competition and increased emphasis on new technology drive the need for creative engineers.

A goal of the study is to shape graduate education best practices for recruitment, retention, and training in engineering, particularly for doctoral students in engineering, but elements of this work will be transferable to other populations within graduate education. Through a mixed methods study of graduate student motivational goal setting and identity formation the following research questions will be answered: 1. What are the identity and motivation profiles of engineering doctoral students, which are based on previous academic and research experiences in STEM? 2. How does the STEM community influence identity formation and motivational goal setting processes of engineering doctoral students? 3. How do these processes related to identity formation and motivation influence engineering graduate student retention, productivity, and pursuit of doctoral level engineering careers? In the initial quantitative phase, development, administration, and analysis of a survey to assess the experiences of a nationally-representative sample of currently-enrolled engineering graduate students will be completed. Data will be analyzed using advanced clustering techniques to create attitudinal profiles that reflect graduate students' identity and motivation. To maximize the sample size, students will be recruited through engineering societies and targeted solicitations to graduate engineering programs. In the qualitative second phase up to 50 students of varying attitudinal profiles will be selected to study the influence of graduate experiences on identity development and motivational goal setting. Using a phenomenological lens, students will be interviewed about their experiences in graduate engineering education. Through the mixed-methods approach, the interactions of students' identities and motivation will be captured and how academic experiences influence these profiles will be determined. Results can be used to inform programmatic decisions in graduate programs and facilitate interventions that promote motivation and identity development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To address the goals of the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, this ECR project generated foundational knowledge about how doctoral engineering student experiences influence identity formation and motivation and therefore affect retention, persistence, and productivity. While motivation and identity have been widely studied at the undergraduate level, graduate-level studies are less available. Engineering is the least studied field in graduate education, and if studied, it is often combined with other STEM fields, despite unique disciplinary cultures. Engineering?s focus on career preparation and industry-relevant experiences can also lead to limited development of research-oriented skills and future goals by engineering students. Students coming in with narrow definitions of research, particularly research in an engineering context, can experience a mismatch between their identities, their future goals, and expectations for them as researchers. The work conducted in this proposal highlighted the ways that graduate contexts do and do not support graduate engineering student identity and motivation development.

Large scale qualitative work (n= 41) and a nationally representative survey of engineering graduate students (n = 2,343) indicated that existing theoretical models of identity and motivations for the future are transferable to graduate engineering students when modified for the graduate context. Engineering graduate students? were shaped by their perceptions of performance/competence, interest, and recognition in graduate specific domains of engineering, science, and research. Engineering graduate students' motivations for the future were shaped heavily by their graduate program experiences and their perceptions of employability in their desired positions after graduation.

Using updated theoretical models of identity based on early-stage research in this project, results indicated that women and people of Color feel less recognized as engineers than their male or White peers. Supporting previous findings, results showed that positive advisor relationships are fundamental for supporting students? identities and both the Masters and Doctoral levels. In addition to advisor relationships, peer relationships improve engineering graduate student identities. These benefits of peer relationships are not equitable. For example, women of Color see less benefit from peer relationships than men of Color.

Building off identity results, engineering graduate students displayed increased motivation for the future when able to leverage their past experiences. Additionally, an in-depth analysis of results suggested that the development of a successful graduate student engineer identity relied heavily on integrating existing, deeply-entrenched identities and motivations. Students? mental and emotional resources were divided and often pitted against each other without this integration, resulting in role conflict, disidentification, and withdrawal. This trend highlights the importance of environments that emphasize rich interconnections between personal, cultural, and engineering experiences and motivation so that students? identities will be consolidated rather than fragmented. Significant across the motivational landscape of engineering graduate education indicated that students struggled to plan beyond graduation. 

The narratives suggested that students have a general trajectory but devote minimal time to finding steps and opportunities until they near graduation. Additionally, when asked about what students find useful while in graduate school, most students noted the equipment they work with and the communication skills they acquire. This finding indicated that the technical expertise these students develop is not considered useful for their future careers. Instead, students focused on getting the degree for an increase in opportunities and autonomy in their future. 

The research project provides a foundation for changing how students? identities and future-oriented motivations are fostered in engineering graduate programs. To date, a revised set of mentoring practices based on the above evidence have been implemented across multiple engineering departments to promote student development and goals for the future. Additionally, theoretical models developed as part of this work are being applied to address issues of mental health, bias, and discrimination in graduate engineering programs. Further application of these results to create intentional change in engineering graduate education may stem the tide of student attrition, address a growing mental health crisis, and potentially remove barriers to the diversification of graduate programs.
